modules.Plot.parallel_plot(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, column_color: str, s: int = 0, e: int = 5, show: bool = True, color_scale: List[str] = ['rgb(0, 147, 146)', 'rgb(114, 170, 161)', 'rgb(177, 199, 179)', 'rgb(241, 234, 200)', 'rgb(229, 185, 173)', 'rgb(217, 137, 148)', 'rgb(208, 88, 126)'], width: int = 1200, height: int = 620) → plotly.missing_ipywidgets.FigureWidget[source]¶

Realize a parallel plot. A parallel plot is a plot similar to line plt. Check it out the parallel plot documentation.

Keyword Arguments

  • df (-) –

  • column_color (-) –

Kwargs

  • s: start column to be plotted. REMEBER to include the column_color in this range.

  • e: end column

  • show: show the figure after generated

  • color_scale: it’s a range of hexadecimal colors. The default value is plotly.express.colors.diverging.Tealrose

  • width: the figure width

  • height: the figure height

Returns

A generated figure object

Generates a pie plot for a given dataframe.

Keyword Arguments

  • col (-) –

Kwargs

  • threshold: The value that used to group elements in this column

  • show: If setled, show the generated plot too

Returns

modules.Plot.spider_plot(categories: List[str], show: bool = True, r1: Optional[List[float]] = None, r1_name: Optional[str] = None, r2: Optional[List[float]] = None, r2_name: Optional[str] = None) → plotly.missing_ipywidgets.FigureWidget[source]¶

Does spider plot. Accept at max 2 elements. By default, it assumes that only are possible values between 0..1

Keyword Arguments

categories (-) –

Kwargs

  • r1: List[Float] Mapped values following categories order

  • r1_name: (str) Name of this section

  • show: OPTIONAL if settled will not show the figure at end

  • r2: OPTIONAL. List[Float] Mapped values following categories order

  • r2_name: OPTIONAL. (str) Name of this section

Returns

  • A figure plotly object (only access by ipykernel)

Score module¶

This module contains methods to:

  • Read a given student history (pdf), and parse it into a dataframe. parse_pdf()

  • Save the dataframe into a json. save_analysis()

  • Load the json equivalent to a dataframe object. read_json()

Todo

Implement tests for:

  • test_read_json

  • test_save_analysis

  • Testtest_parse_pdf

Implement loggers for:

  • parse_pdf

modules.Score.parse_pdf(studentId: str, inputDir: str, outDir: Optional[str] = None) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]¶

Read a student score and parse it to a json file

Parameters

  • studentId – The student unique id

  • inputDir – Directory where are placed the input files. (Based on current file)

Keyword Arguments

outDir – Directory to save the json objects. (Based on project dir)

Returns

Returns a dataframe containing the parsed value

Return type

DataFrame

modules.Score.read_json(filepath: str) → <module ‘json’ from ‘c:\program files\python39\lib\json\__init__.py’>[source]¶

Read a json file equivalent to student’s grid.

Parameters

filepath – path where to load the json file

Returns

The equivalent json representation

Return type

json

Note

It’s just a shortcut to read the file

Example

>>> from modules.score import read_json
>>> import os
>>> p = os.path.realpath("../file.json")
>>> read_json(p)

Save the score loaded into a json object. Usually, this methods depends of parse_pdf().

Parameters

  • out – the data to store

  • filename – the name of generated file

  • dirname – place to put the output file

Skillset module¶

This module contains all functions used to read the CSV files under a specified directory. It’s responsable to parse the data obtained in the Google Sheets

Todo

Implement loggers for

  • read_csvs

Implement tests for:

  • test_read_csvs

  • merge_data

modules.Skillset.merge_data(dataframes: List[pandas.core.frame.DataFrame]) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]¶

It performs the join of multiple dataframes objects into a single one, basing on a specified method. By default, it does a mean operation, ie.:

\[\frac{\sum_{i=0}^N \text{dataframes}_i}{N}\]
Parameters

dataframes – A list of dataframes to be merged.

Returns

A single dataframe based on values passed through. mean(dataframes)

Return type

pandas.DataFrame

modules.Skillset.read_csvs(sheetsDir: str) → List[pandas.core.frame.DataFrame][source]¶

Open a directory and read all csv files inside. This function clean some unusefull elements based on researches models.

Parameters

sheetsDir – Directory to search for csv files.

Returns

A list of pandas dataframes

Return type

List[pandas.DataFrame]

Bases: Exception

message – The value to raise

modules.util.average(args: List[float], roundp: int = 4) → float[source]¶
modules.util.average(args: List[List[List[float]]], roundp: int = 4) → numpy.ndarray

Calculate the mean of a given amount of values. It can performs the mean over List[List[float]] or List[float].

Equation that describes the behavior when using a list of floats:

\[\frac{\sum_{i=0}^N\text{arg}_i}{N}\]

Equation that describes the behavior when using matrices:

\[\text{output}_\text{(i,j)} = \frac{\sum_{n=0}^N \text{Matrix}[n]_\text{(i,j)}}{N} \text{, } \forall \text{ }0 \leq i,j < N\]
Parameters

args – A list of floats or a list of matrices

Keyword Arguments

roundp – Number of decimal places used to round

Raises

  • MinimumLenghtError – if the len(args) are less than 2

  • TypeError – if the input type are not List[List[List[float]]] or List[float]

Examples

Using a list of float

>>> l = [1, 1, 1, 1, 1]
>>> average(l)
1

Using a list of list of floats

>>> from copy import deepcopy
>>> a = [
...     [1, 1, 1],
...     [1, 1, 1],
... ]
>>> b = deepcopy(a)
>>> result = average([a,b])
>>> expected_result = deepcopy(a)
>>> # iterate and raise an error. P.S.: It won't throw any error
>>> for row in range(2):
...    for col in range(3):
...        assert result[row][col] == expected_result[row][col]

Changed in version 0.0.9: Create two functions, splicing documentation according with param type.

Changed in version 0.0.7: Fixed the problem with multiples pointers to the same memory address.

modules.util.calc_ahp_for_new_mat(matrices: Dict[str, Union[List[List[float]], float]]) → Dict[str, Union[List[float], float]][source]¶

This function are only used to calculate AHP for each matrices

Parameters

matrices – A dictionary mapping a matrix to a matrix or a float

Returns

A dictionary containing the priority vector of each matrix.

Return type

Dict[str, Union[List[float], float]]

Important

This method only calculate AHP again. It doesn’t check if AHP are valid or not

modules.util.calc_mean_matrix(data: List[modules.ahp.Types.FormData]) → Dict[str, Union[List[List[float]], float]][source]¶

It calculates the mean matrix that corresponds to the mean of all data.

Attention

  • It ignores matrices fullfilled with 0 for the mean calculation.

  • It also ignores matrices where the ahp wasn’t valid

Parameters

data – The list of data obtained from modules.ahp.Database.AhpForm.findByType()

Returns

A dictionary mapping each matrix to its equivalent mean matrix.

Return type

Dict[str, Union[float, List[List[float]]]]

modules.util.errprint(msg: str) → None[source]¶

Print some error message, returning a different value from default (1).

Parameters

msg – Message to be shown

modules.util.get_competences_and_consistency(data: List[modules.ahp.Types.FormData], tt: modules.ahp.Types.FormDataType) → Tuple[pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, pandas.core.frame.DataFrame][source]¶

It calculates the ahp for each data

Parameters

  • data – A list of data that will be placed as rows in result dataframes

  • tt – Type of each list of data. See more on modules.ahp.Types.FormDataType

Returns

A tuple that contains:

  1. The mongo competences calculated and parsed to each competence

  2. The mongo consistency for each matrix

Return type

Tuple[pd.DataFrame, pd.DataFrame]
